text:
The Gentlewoman's

Yolks of two Eggs 1/2, one Yolk of
Dissagot, and 1/4 more yolks according
to the quantity of your Ale: beat them
very well, and take away the skin of the
yolks, and then the Ale boils put them
in, and keep them boiling continuously:
and when it has cooked a while, sweeten it
with Sugar; and if it be to eat, cut two
or three loaves of White bread, take them
dry, and put them to the Candle, but if it
be to distill put in sons.

To Stew Beef.

Take a good Rump of Beef cut from
the bones, shred Turnips and Carrots
small, with Spinach and Lettuce, put
all in a Pan and let it stew four hours
with so much Water, and a quart of
White-wine as will cover it, some
Pepper and Salt: when it is stewed
then put in a wine-glass full of good El-
der Vinegar, and serve it with Sip-
pits.

To Boyl a Gammon of Bacon.

Water your Gammon of Bacon
twenty-four hours, then put it into a
deep Kettle with Sweet Hay, let it boil
softly six or seven hours, and then take
it up with a Scummer and a Piats, and
take off the Skin whole, then stick your
Gam-

Cabin'et Unlocked.

Gammon full of Cloves, and strew on
some grols Pepper, then cut your skin
like sippits to garnish your Gammon:
and when you serve it, stick it with
Bay-leaves.

To Boyl Brawn.

Water your Brawn twenty-four
hours, wash and scrape it four or five
times, then take it out of the water and
lay it on a clean Table, and throw an
handful of Salt on every Collar, then
bind them up as fast as you can with
Hemp or Hals, and put them in your
Kettle, when the Water boils, and
the scum arises, take it away: Let it
boil so tender that you may thrust a straw
through it, then let it cool till the next
morning, and serve.

To make a White-pot.

Take the milk and sweet Cream,
and boil it with good Rose of Sugar and
Cinnamon, a little Rose-water: then
take it from the fire and put into it clean
picked Rice, but not so much as to make
it thick, and let it steep therein till it
be cold: then put in the Yolks of six
Eggs and two whites, Currants, Nut-
meg and Salt: then put it into the Pan
or Pot, as thin as if it were a Custard,
